poem:
Title: A Cairn for Ellen Strange

Upon a moor,
where raw winds wane,
an ancient cairn 
whispers her name.
Ellen Strange we recall,
by stones, small.
Each picked and placed,
a centuries-past face.
Memory etched onto ridge and rill,
a testament of stubborn will,
to honor the fallen,
the battered and bruised,
with each stone lain,
resilience is refused to be abused.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Commemorating Ellen Strange and all other victims of domestic violence | Letter I was pleased to read the letter by Pam Roud (12 March) regarding a statue to commemorate the women killed by men. Living in Cambridgeshire, she may be unaware that on Holcombe Moor, Ramsbottom, there is an ancient cairn that marks the spot where Ellen Strange was killed by her husband in 1761. Local people since then have placed stones on this cairn". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
